questions.text: All of the following physiological changes in the cardiovascular system during pregnancy increase except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: Option B

Explanation

Blood pressure reduces because there is decrease in peripheral systemic vascular resistance due to the vasodilation in pregnancy 

Note - Ejection fraction in normal pregnancy remains unchanged.

questions.text: A 28 Y/o pregnant woman at 24 weeks gestation comes to the prenatal clinic for a routine check-up. She mentions she was diagnosed with congenital heart disease as a child but hasn't had any significant symptoms in recent years. Which of the following is the most common congenital heart disease seen in pregnant women?
questions.solution:
Atrial septal defect:

  • ASD is the most common congenital heart disease seen in pregnant women.
  • ASD is a true hole in atrial septum, and secundum type defects account for 70%.
  • Most ASD are asymptomatic till the 3rd/4th decade of life.
  • Pregnancy with an unrepaired ASD is well tolerated until and unless pulmonary hypertension develops.
  • The risk of ASD-related stroke is higher in pregnant women than in nonpregnant women.

Most common congenital valvular heart disease in pregnancy is mitral valve prolapse. Most common heart disease affecting pregnant women in India is rheumatic heart disease and that too mitral stenosis. Most common heart disease responsible for maternal mortality in our country is mitral stenosis

M/C congenital heart disease seen in pregnant women

Atrial septal defect

M/C cyanotic heart disease seen in pregnancy

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option A)

M/C acquired valvular disease in pregnancy

Mitral stenosis (Option B)

M/C congenital valvular disease in pregnancy

Mitral valve prolapse associated mitral stenosis. (Option D)

questions.text: A 32 Y/o female in her third trimester of pregnancy with known case of Mitral Stenosis, presents to the clinic with complaints of increasing shortness of breath, fatigue, and swelling in her legs. On examination, she has an increased heart rate, jugular venous distension, B/L crepts on chest auscultation and pitting edema in her lower extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for the patient?

choices.text: Ace inhibitor and restrict sodium intake
Immediate delivery of the fetus for relieving cardiac stress.

questions.solution:
Based on the above scenario, the patient is most likely suffering from Heart failure during pregnancy. Diuretics (furosemide) and fluid restriction are the initial management in patients with heart failure in pregnancy.

Beta-blockers (Option A) such as carvedilol can be given to patients with acute heart failure, but this is not the initial management, and complete bed rest increases the risk of thromboembolism in pregnant women.

 

ACE inhibitors (Option C) are contraindicated in pregnant women because of their effect on fetal kidneys.

 

Immediate delivery of the fetus (Option D) is not indicated unless there is fetal distress or when medical management is not sufficient.

questions.text: A 30 Y/o woman with a known history of heart disease is planning to conceive. She visits her cardiologist to discuss the potential risks associated with pregnancy, given her cardiac condition. Which of the following heart conditions is a contraindication to pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Eisenmenger syndrome is a late sequel of acyanotic heart diseases such as ASD, VSD or PDA. It is a severe form of pulmonary arterial hypertension, and pregnancy is contraindicated in such patients.

Eisenmenger syndrome is the cardiac disease with the highest risk of maternal mortality.

Cardiovascular conditions contraindicated to pregnancy:

  • Pulmonary arterial hypertension
  • Severe ventricular dysfunction (NYHA III-IV or LVEF <30%)
  • Prior peripartum cardiomyopathy with residual effects
  • Severe left heart obstruction
  • Severe aortic dilation
  • Severe coarctation
  • Severe AS and MS
  • Marfan syndrome

For such conditions, pregnancy is contraindicated. If pregnancy is wanted, then monthly cardiac consultations should be done at a tertiary care hospital.

 

ASD, VSD and PDA (Options B, C, & D) themselves are not contraindications for pregnancy.

questions.text: A 32 Y/o pregnant woman at 28 weeks gestation presents with complaints of progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, palpitations, and swelling in B/L ankles. On physical examination, the physician observes persistent jugular venous distension, a systolic murmur, and bilateral pitting edema. Which of the following is most concerning for heart disease in this patient?

choices.text: Jugular venous distension with systolic murmur

questions.solution:
Based on the above scenario, the patient is most likely suffering from Heart failure in pregnancy. Persistent jugular venous dilation along with systolic heart murmur is classically seen in patients with heart failure.

 

Indicators of heart disease in pregnancy:

  • Fatigue and bilateral pitting edema can also be seen in a normal pregnant woman (Options B & C).
  • Dyspnea can be because of other reasons also (Option A)

questions.text: 32 y/o woman at 12 weeks gestation with a history of mitral valve prolapse denies chest pain, shortness of breath, and syncope. What is her prognosis for this pregnancy?

choices.text: Good prognosis with minimal risk of complications.
Poor prognosis with a high risk of heart failure.
Moderate prognosis with potential for arrhythmias.

questions.solution:
• Pregnancy may improve the alignment of the mitral valve due to increased blood volume, leading to fewer complications. Because the patient is asymptomatic (denying chest pain, shortness of breath, and syncope), she is likely to have a good prognosis.

 

Prognosis

Heart Condition

Good prognosis with minimal complications
(Option A)
  • Mitral valve prolapse without pathological myxomatous degeneration.
  • Small to moderate-sized ventricular septal defects (VSDs).
  • Repaired transposition of the great vessels.
  • Atrial septal defect (ASD) unless pulmonary hypertension has developed.
  • Mild MS and AS.

Poor prognosis with high risk of heart failure.

(Option B)
  • Eisenmenger syndrome.
  • Severe aortic stenosis.
  • Severe coarctation of the aorta.
  • Uncorrected Cyanotic Heart Disease.
  • Idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension.
  • Prior myocardial infarction, especially with diabetes-associated ischemic heart disease.
  • Marfan Syndrome with Aortic Root Dilation

Moderate prognosis with potential for arrhythmias.

(Option C)
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
  • Dilated Cardiomyopathy
  • Mitral stenosis.
  • Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia.

Uncertain prognosis requiring frequent monitoring (Option D)
  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy.
  • Mechanical heart valve.

questions.text: A 30 y/o woman at 37 weeks gestation with a history of coarctation of the aorta presents for a prenatal visit. She is currently asymptomatic. Her echocardiogram shows good left ventricular function, but her aortic root diameter is measured at 4.7 cm. Which of the following is the most appropriate mode of delivery?

choices.text: Proceed with an elective Cesarean section.
Plan to induce labor at 39 weeks and attempt a vaginal delivery.
Cesarean section only if there is cardiac decompensation.
Allow for spontaneous labor and attempt a vaginal delivery.

questions.solution:
• Women with an aortic root diameter > 4.5 cm should undergo an elective Cesarean section.
  • Because pregnancy increases the risk of aortic dissection in women with coarctation of the aorta, and the risk is further elevated during labor and delivery.
  • An aortic root diameter > 4.5 cm poses a significant risk of dissection and rupture, which is often fatal.

 

Cesarean Section in Heart Disease

Indications

Explanation

Aortic root dilatation: > 4 cm

Increases the risk of aortic dissection. 

Aortic Aneurysms

Coarctation of the Aorta

Severe Aortic Stenosis

Have a fixed cardiac output, making them vulnerable to hemodynamic changes during labor.

Recent MI

Physiological stress of labor and delivery might be too much for a heart recently recovering from an MI, causing increased complications.

Congestive Heart Failure

With limited cardiac reserve, the stress of labor could precipitate a cardiac decompensation event. However, aggressive medical stabilization of pulmonary edema is preferred, followed by vaginal delivery if feasible.

NYHA Class III or IV

Limitations on physical activity. Labor is strenuous and could lead to serious complications.

Warfarin use in last 2 weeks

Due to the risk of fetal intracerebral hemorrhage, as the fetal liver requires up to two weeks to metabolize warfarin.

Need for emergency valve replacement immediately after delivery

Due to the high risk of hemodynamic instability and cardiac decompensation during labor in patients with severe valve disease.

questions.text: 30 y/o woman with a history of rheumatic heart disease presents at 38 weeks gestation with mitral stenosis and new-onset dyspnea. She is currently in labor. Her mitral valve area is estimated to be 1.2 cm2. Which of the following interventions is most likely to be CONTRAINDICATED in her management?
questions.solution:
Avoid using methyl ergometrine (methergine) for postpartum hemorrhage prevention, as it can suddenly increase preload, potentially leading to heart failure.

IV methergine will cause forceful tetanic contractions. Extra blood will seep into the maternal circulation which increase the venous return and put extra load on the heart.

questions.text: 35 y/o woman with 6 weeks postpartum has a history of rheumatic heart disease, specifically mitral stenosis, and experienced an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. She is currently asymptomatic. Her echocardiogram shows mild improvement in her mitral valve area compared to her pre-pregnancy assessment. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?

choices.text: Continue routine cardiology follow-up for heart failure.
Refer for repeat percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty.
Start anticoagulation with warfarin to prevent thromboembolic events.
Advise against future pregnancies due to risks of cardiac complications.

questions.solution:
• Women with a history of rheumatic heart disease, especially mitral stenosis, require close monitoring postpartum.
  • Despite an uncomplicated pregnancy and mild improvement in her mitral valve area, she remains at risk for delayed complications like heart failure.
  • Regular follow-up allows for early detection and management of any arising issues.

 

Delayed complications of heart disease in pregnancy

Complications

Management

Cardiac Rupture

Planned non-invasive surgery like balloon mitral valvotomy for mitral stenosis, preferably done in the second trimester, can help prevent heart failure.

Infective Endocarditis

Avoid contact with people with respiratory infections. Administer pneumococcal vaccination if not already administered, and yearly influenza vaccination.

Thromboembolic Phenomenon

Low molecular weight heparin anticoagulation when the ejection fraction is 30-35% due to the increased risk of left ventricular thrombi.

Mitral Valve Prolapse

Continuous routine monitoring and follow-up.

Arrhythmias

Continue beta-blockers, preferably propranolol, throughout pregnancy and the postpartum period to lower the risk of torsades de pointes.

Postpartum Heart Failure

Keep the patient in a high-risk ward or ICU for observation for the first 24 hours and administer furosemide immediately after delivery to decrease preload on the heart.

 

Percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty (Option B) is a viable option for symptomatic mitral stenosis during pregnancy; it is not routinely performed postpartum in asymptomatic patients

Anticoagulation (Option C) is crucial for patients with mechanical valves and is not routinely indicated unless there is a history of atrial fibrillation or prior thromboembolic events.


A history of well-managed mitral stenosis alone does not contraindicate future pregnancies (Option D)

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman with a history of mechanical mitral valve replacement, is seen at 6 weeks gestation and is currently on warfarin and aspirin. What is the most appropriate next step in management regarding her anticoagulation?

choices.text: Switch to unfractionated heparin throughout pregnancy.
Switch to a low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) throughout pregnancy.
Switch to LMWH now and transition to warfarin in the second trimester.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Switch to LMWH now and transition to warfarin in the second trimester.

Explanation:

Recommendations for anticoagulants in pregnancy:

  • Pregnancy significantly increases the risk of thromboembolism, but anticoagulation is vital for women with mechanical heart valves to prevent valve thrombosis.
  • Warfarin is teratogenic, potentially causing miscarriages, stillbirths, and a constellation of birth defects known as fetal warfarin syndrome. (Option A)
  • Heparin, in both unfractionated (UFH) and low-molecular-weight (LMWH) forms, is considered safer for the fetus during pregnancy as it does not cross the placenta.
  • UFH, even at full anticoagulation doses, is considered inadequate for preventing valve thrombosis in pregnant women with mechanical heart valves. (Option B)
  • LMWH is associated with a lower risk of valve thrombosis compared to UFH, making it a preferred choice for many pregnant women requiring anticoagulation.
  • A common approach is to start LMWH during the first trimester to minimize fetal risks, then switch to warfarin after the first trimester for better valve thrombosis protection. Near term, warfarin is discontinued to reduce bleeding risks during labor, then restarted shortly after delivery. (Option C) (Option D)
  • Regular monitoring of anticoagulation levels (INR for warfarin, anti-Xa levels for LMWH) is essential.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of repaired tetralogy of Fallot comes to your clinic seeking advice about pregnancy. She has no significant symptoms, and her latest echocardiogram shows good ventricular function with no residual defects. According to the World Health Organization (WHO) classification for maternal cardiovascular risk, which WHO Risk Class does this patient belong to?
questions.solution:
WHO Risk Class II includes conditions such as repaired tetralogy of Fallot, which indicates a small increased risk of maternal mortality or moderate increase in morbidity.

WHO Classification for Maternal Cardiovascular Risk

The WHO classification evaluates the risk of complications during pregnancy for women with various cardiovascular conditions, divided into four classes based on severity and potential risk to the mother and fetus:

 

WHO Risk Class

Description

Includes Conditions Such As

I

No detectable increased risk of maternal mortality and no or mild increase in morbidity.
  • Uncomplicated, small, or mild congenital heart defects (e.g., pulmonary stenosis, PDA, MVP)
  • Successfully repaired simple lesions (ASD, VSD, PDA, anomalous pulmonary venous drainage)
  • Isolated atrial or ventricular ectopic beats

II

Small increased risk of maternal mortality or moderate increase in morbidity.
  • Unoperated atrial or ventricular septal defect
  • Repaired TOF
  • Most arrhythmias
  • Mild left ventricular impairment
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
  • Native or tissue valvular heart disease not in WHO I or IV
  • Marfan syndrome without aortic dilatation
  • Aorta <45 mm in aortic disease associated with bicuspid aortic valve
  • Repaired Coarctation

III

Significantly increased risk of maternal mortality or severe morbidity. Expert counseling required.
  • Mechanical valve
  • Cyanotic heart disease (unrepaired)
  • Other complex congenital heart disease
  • Aortic dilatation 4-4.5 cm in Marfan syndrome
  • Aortic dilatation 4.5-5 cm in aortic disease associated with bicuspid aortic valve Repaired
  • Coarctation with significant residual impairment

IV

Extremely high risk of maternal mortality or severe morbidity; pregnancy contraindicated.
  • Pulmonary arterial hypertension of any cause
  • Severe systemic ventricular dysfunction (LVEF <30%, NYHA III-IV)
  • Previous peripartum cardiomyopathy with any residual impairment of left ventricular function
  • Severe symptomatic mitral or aortic stenosis
  • Marfan syndrome with aorta dilated >4.5 cm
  • Aortic dilation >5 cm in aortic disease associated with bicuspid aortic valve Native
  • Severe coarctation

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman who recently delivered a healthy baby presents to the emergency department with symptoms of shortness of breath and fatigue. An echocardiogram reveals left ventricular systolic dysfunction with a dilated left ventricle. Her medical history is significant for twin gestation and preeclampsia during her recent pregnancy. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms, recent pregnancy with twin gestation, and history of preeclampsia are consistent with peripartum cardiomyopathy.

Peripartum Cardiomyopathy (PPCM)

PPCM is a form of nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy linked to pregnancy, sharing a genetic predisposition with familial and sporadic idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy.

Diagnostic Criteria (Pearson, 2000)

  • Development of cardiac failure in the last month of pregnancy or within 5 months postpartum.
  • Absence of an identifiable cause for the cardiac failure.
  • No recognizable heart disease prior to the last month of pregnancy.
  • Left ventricular systolic dysfunction (depressed ejection fraction, fractional shortening, and dilated left ventricle).

Hypertensive heart failure (Option A) is typically associated with long-standing hypertension and not not present acutely like in this scenario.

Viral myocarditis (Option C) is less commonly associated with recent childbirth and would not typically be related to the history of multiple gestation and preeclampsia

Idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy (Option D)  is a diagnosis of exclusion and is not specifically associated with recent pregnancy

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 28 weeks of gestation presents with shortness of breath, fatigue, and occasional palpitations. She has a history of rheumatic heart disease with mitral stenosis. On examination, she has a tachycardia and an elevated jugular venous pressure. An echocardiogram reveals a mitral valve area of 1.8 cm², left atrial enlargement, and pulmonary hypertension. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

choices.text: Limited physical activity, dietary sodium restriction, and β-blocker therapy
Intravenous furosemide and initiation of digoxin

questions.solution:
Limited physical activity: Reduces the cardiac workload and helps manage symptoms.

Dietary sodium restriction: Helps to prevent fluid retention and pulmonary congestion.

β-blocker therapy: Slows the heart rate, reducing the mitral gradient and preventing tachycardia-induced pulmonary edema.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman at 34 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain radiating to her left arm. An ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads, and her serum high-sensitivity troponin I levels are elevated. The patient is diagnosed with an ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

choices.text: Immediate induction of labor to reduce cardiac stress
Administration of aspirin, heparin, and initiation of percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)
Conservative management with bed rest and observation
Administration of intravenous thrombolytics and immediate cesarean delivery

questions.solution:
• The management of acute MI in pregnant women is similar to that in nonpregnant patients.
  • The initial treatment should include aspirin and heparin to manage the thrombosis, followed by percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to revascularize the affected coronary artery. PCI is the preferred method as it is effective and safe during pregnancy.
  • Cesarean delivery is reserved for obstetrical indications after sufficient infarct healing. Epidural analgesia is preferred for labor pain management. (Option D)
  • Immediate Induction of Labor is not the immediate priority for managing a STEMI. (Option A)
  • Conservative Management with Bed Rest and Observation would not address the immediate need for myocardial reperfusion and could lead to a worsening of the myocardial infarction. (Option C)
